name: Timisoara
fun_fact: Fun fact: Timi»ôoara was the first city in Europe to have electric street lights in 1884 (second in the world after New York), beating Paris and London by years. In December 1989, it became the first Romanian city to overthrow communism, sparking the revolution that ended Ceau»ôescu's regime three days later

hero_dishes.name: Sarmale (Cabbage Rolls)
hero_dishes.description: Tender cabbage leaves wrapped around a savory mix of ground pork, rice, and spices, slow-cooked for hours in rich tomato sauce. Served with sour cream, polenta, and spicy peppers
hero_dishes.origin_story: Romania's ultimate comfort food, traditionally made for Christmas and weddings. The recipe came from Ottoman times but was perfected by Romanian grandmothers who insist on using sauerkraut leaves, not fresh cabbage. Making sarmale is an all-day affair - families gather to roll hundreds at once
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Casa Timi»ô (traditional with sour cream and pepper), Casa Bunicii (grandmother's house - the name says it all), Miorita (huge portions, rustic decor)

hero_dishes.name: Mici (Mititei - Little Sausages)
hero_dishes.description: Small skinless grilled sausages made from a secret blend of beef, pork, lamb, garlic, and spices. Juicy, garlicky, and slightly smoky, always served with mustard and fresh bread
hero_dishes.origin_story: Born in Bucharest in the 1800s when an inn ran out of sausage casings and grilled the meat mixture anyway. The name means 'little ones.' Every Romanian claims their region makes them best. The secret is the meat-to-fat ratio and leaving them to rest overnight so spices penetrate. Grilled over charcoal, never gas
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Nora Restaurant (famous for generous mici portions), Miorita (absolutely massive servings), Beraria 700 (grilled fresh on outdoor grill since 1761)

hero_dishes.name: Papana»ôi
hero_dishes.description: Fried sweet cheese doughnuts the size of your fist, topped with sour cream and sweet jam (usually blueberry or sour cherry). Crispy outside, fluffy inside, ridiculously indulgent
hero_dishes.origin_story: The Romanian dessert that makes tourists' eyes widen in shock at the portion size. Made with fresh cow cheese (telemea or br√¢nzƒÉ de vaci), these were originally peasant food but became restaurant favorites. The combo of sweet and sour is quintessentially Romanian
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Casa Bunicii & Craft Rooftop, Miorita, Casa Timi»ô (with traditional cozonac sweet bread too)

hero_dishes.name: Roast Duck with Red Wine Sauce
hero_dishes.description: Whole duck roasted until the skin crackles, served with rich red wine reduction and buttery polenta or mashed potatoes
hero_dishes.origin_story: Timi»ôoara's Austro-Hungarian heritage shows in this dish - more refined than typical Romanian fare. The city was called 'Little Vienna' for good reason. Duck farming thrived around the Banat region's wetlands, making this a local specialty
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Casa Timi»ô (oven-baked duck with red wine sauce), Miorita (rustic preparation)

signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Always served in small glasses before meals as an aperitif. Homemade batches are a point of pride - every Romanian grandfather has a secret recipe. Never refuse when offered, it's insulting. Toast with 'Noroc!' (Good luck!). Follow immediately with pickles or sausage

signature_drinks.name: Timi»ôoreana Beer
signature_drinks.description: Local lager brewed in Timi»ôoara since 1718 - Romania's oldest beer brand. Crisp, light, perfect for washing down mici and sarmale
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Served ice-cold in half-liter glasses. Beraria 700 has brewed house beer since 1761 in the old fortress. Beer culture here rivals Prague - the first brewery in present-day Romania was established in Timi»ôoara in 1718. Pair with grilled meats, always

food_culture_notes: Timi»ôoara is the only European city with three state theatres in different languages (Romanian, German, Hungarian) in one building - multicultural heritage
Called 'Little Vienna' for Secession and Baroque architecture - the Austro-Hungarian influence is everywhere, including food
The 1989 anti-communist revolution started here on December 15 with lit candles and peaceful protests
First European city with electric street lights (1884) - commemorative lamp still functions in 700 Market
